Ring-opening copolymerization of CO2 with epoxides catalyzed by binary catalysts containing half salen aluminum compounds and quaternary phosphonium salt Sourav Singha Roy a Sriparna Sarkar a P.K.Sudhadevi Antharjanam b Debashis Chakraborty a ⁎ a Department of Chemistry, Organometallics and Polymer Chemistry Laboratory, Indian Institute of Technology Madras, Chennai, Tamil Nadu 600036, India Department of Chemistry Organometallics and Polymer Chemistry Laboratory, Indian Institute of Technology Madras Chennai Tamil Nadu 600036 India aDepartment of Chemistry, Organometallics and Polymer Chemistry Laboratory, Indian Institute of Technology Madras, Chennai, Tamil Nadu 600036, India b Sophisticated Analytical Instrument Facility, Indian Institute of Technology Madras, Chennai, Tamil Nadu 600036, India Sophisticated Analytical Instrument Facility Indian Institute of Technology Madras Chennai Tamil Nadu 600036 India bSophisticated Analytical Instrument Facility, Indian Institute of Technology Madras, Chennai, Tamil Nadu 600036, India ⁎ Corresponding author. The synthesis and characterization of two different categories of Al(III) compounds supported by unsymmetrical phenoxy-imine ligands with furan-2-ylmethanimine and thiophen-2-ylmethanimine side arms is described. Reactions of the ligands with Al(CH3)3 in a 1:1 and 2:1 stoichiometric ratio resulted in the formation of the corresponding monosubstituted and disubstituted Al(III) compounds in quantitative yields. These compounds were fully characterized using various spectroscopic techniques and elemental analysis. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies revealed that the Al(III) center in the monosubstituted compounds adopt a distorted tetrahedral geometry while those in the disubstituted compounds adopt a distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry with a geometric index τ = 0.72. These compounds along with tetraphenylphosphonium chloride (TPPCl) form a binary catalyst system for the ring-opening copolymerization (ROCOP) of CO2 with cyclohexene oxide (CHO) and propylene oxide (PO). They show notable activity producing alternating polycarbonate with TOF up to 107 h−1 and high selectivity (carbonate linkages > 80%). The catalytic activities of the compounds have been investigated by varying the substituent in the phenolate core and in the imine backbone. Graphical abstract The synthesis and characterization of two different categories of Al(III) compounds supported by unsymmetrical phenoxy-imine ligands with furan-2-ylmethanimine and thiophen-2-ylmethanimine side arms is described. These compounds along with tetraphenylphosphonium chloride (TPPCl) form a binary catalyst system for the ring-opening copolymerization (ROCOP) of CO2 with cyclohexene oxide (CHO) and propylene oxide (PO). Image, graphical abstract Keywords Phenoxy-imine Al(III) ROCOP CO2 Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction In the present era, the central focus of research both in academia and industries is directed towards designing new materials, so that usage of commodities derived from non-renewable sources is minimized. Thus, researchers worldwide are trying to find alternatives to fossil fuel-based materials such that the raw materials for their manufacture are partially or fully derived from renewable feedstocks [1]. In considering the goals for sustainable development, the chemical utilization of CO2 is an excellent route to reduce the aggravated effect of global warming caused due to release of CO2 into the atmosphere from different sources [2]. The significant advantage of using CO2 as one of the constituents for manufacturing synthetic goods is that, it is renewable, inexpensive, and abundant [3]. However, carbon dioxide's high thermodynamic and kinetic stability limits its usage for easy synthetic applications [4]. The ring-opening copolymerization (ROCOP) of CO2 with epoxide is feasible as epoxides possess high ring strain that overcomes the stability of CO2. The ROCOP of epoxide with CO2 generates thermodynamically stable cyclic carbonate and kinetically stable aliphatic polycarbonates (Scheme 1 ) [5]. The cyclic carbonates are mainly used as high boiling solvents and electrolytes in batteries [6]. However, aliphatic polycarbonates are biodegradable [7] and suitable for various applications such as manufacturing electronic, automotive, aircraft, and security components, preparing different parts of mobile phones, data storage devices, construction materials, etc. [8,9]. By choosing a suitable catalyst system, one can regulate the process for producing the polycarbonate fraction as the primary product [10–12]. The choice of an apt catalyst system is crucial to suppress the cyclic carbonate formation, minimize polyether linkages in the polycarbonate chain and regulate the physical parameters of the polymerization, including molecular weight (M n) and molecular weight distribution [13,14]. The recent advances in this area have been described elaborately in some recent reviews [15–20]. The first report on the synthesis of aliphatic polycarbonates dates back to the early discovery of Inoue and coworkers in 1969, employing a heterogeneous catalyst system consisting of diethylzinc and water [21]. Following his success with the heterogeneous catalyst for the ROCOP and considering the advantage of homogeneous catalysts over heterogeneous catalysts, Inoue and Takeda investigated the tetraphenylporphyrin derivative of aluminum for the ROCOP of PO and CO2 [22]. Further, they explored that the catalytic activity is enhanced when the aluminum porphyrin complex is coupled to quaternary ammonium and phosphonium salts. The polymers obtained had comparatively narrow molecular weight distribution [23]. Over the years, numerous homogeneous catalytic systems have been explored for the ROCOP of epoxides with CO2, with the majority of the catalysts containing d-block metals. Compounds of zinc (II) [24–26], chromium (III) [27–29] and, cobalt (III) [30–32] showed high catalytic activity and excellent selectivity towards the formation of linear chain polycarbonate over cyclic carbonate. Williams and coworkers have significantly contributed towards the ROCOP of epoxides with CO2 by employing homodinuclear and heterodinuclear catalysts [33–37]. Most heterodinuclear catalysts usually employ transition metals (Co, Cr, Zn) in conjugation with main group metals (Mg, Al, K, Na) [38–41]. There are few reports in the literature with single-site metal catalysts where the metal ion is a main group metal like magnesium [42], aluminum [43]. In this context, Darensbourg and coworkers have investigated a binary catalytic system consisting of Lewis base and salen-based aluminum complexes towards the ROCOP [44,45]. The major advantage of salen-based ligands is that they are comparatively inexpensive alternatives to porphyrin ligands [46]. Inspired by the success of aluminum complexes supported by salen-based ligands for ROCOP, we became interested to investigate phenoxy-imine (half-salen) containing Al(III) compounds, since phenoxy-imine ligands offer more structural flexibility in comparison to salen analogues and in addition, steric and electronic environment on ligand backbone can be tuned easily [47]. To the best of our knowledge, achiral phenoxy-imine aluminum compounds have been seldom explored for the ROCOP of epoxides with CO2, with only literature report pertaining to dialkyl aluminum complexes reported by Inoue and coworkers where the copolymer yield obtained from dialkyl phenoxy-imine aluminum complex was less compared to monoalkyl salen-based aluminum compound [48]. Herein we synthesized monoalkyl and dialkyl phenoxy-imine Al(III) compounds with the variation of the substituent at the phenolate core and the side arm attached to the imine nitrogen atom. The catalytic activity of our compounds was thoroughly investigated for ROCOP of CO2 with CHO and PO. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Synthesis and characterization Two series of half-salen Al(III) compounds were prepared with achiral unsymmetrical phenoxy-imine ligand backbone, which have furan-2-ylmethanimine and thiophen-2-ylmethanimine as side arms attached to the imine nitrogen atom. The ligands (L1-L6) were synthesized by Schiff base condensation of substituted salicylaldehyde with furan-2-ylmethanimine and thiophen-2-ylmethanimine according to literature reported procedures [49,50]. The ligands L1-L6 were reacted with Al(CH3)3 in a 1:1 and 2:1 stoichiometric ratio in toluene under ambient conditions, resulting in the formation of monosubstituted (1–6) and disubstituted (7–12) products respectively (Scheme 2 ). The progress of these reactions was monitored by the disappearance of the phenolic −OH signal of the ligand (13.01–13.54 ppm) with time in the 1H NMR spectra of different aliquots taken from the reaction mixture. Compounds 1–12 were isolated after removal of the solvent under reduced pressure and were crystallized from toluene to receive analytically pure material in 88–94% yield. The 1H NMR studies of 1–12 revealed all the signals corresponding to the various moieties in the proper integration ratio. The disappearance of the phenolic proton peak of the ligands at (ẟ = 13.10–13.53 ppm) gave evidence for the coordination of ligand oxygen to the Al(III) center. In general, for compounds 1–12, an upfield shift for the imine proton was observed, suggesting the coordination of the ligand nitrogen atom to the Al(III) center. For the dialkyl aluminum compounds (1–6), only a single set of sharp signals was observed for the respective protons [imine protons (δ = 8.05–8.17 ppm), methylene protons (δ = 4.66–4.90 ppm), methyl protons attached to the Al(III) center (-0.81 to -0.88) and aromatic ring protons]. While for the monoalkyl aluminum compounds (7–12), two sets of peaks were observed for the respective protons [imine proton (δ = 8.04–8.18 ppm and δ = 7.86–7.97 ppm), methylene proton (δ = 4.83–5.38 ppm and δ = 4.63–4.83 ppm), methyl protons attached to the Al(III) center (−0.53 to -0.88 ppm and -0.91 to -1.19 ppm) and as well as for the aromatic ring protons]. The two sets of peaks have unequal intensity indicating the presence of two distinct species for compounds 7–12 in solution in different ratio. Among the two species, the probability that one is monoligated aluminum compound is completely neglected as the chemical shift of the methyl proton signal for 7–12 is different from 1 to 6 (Table S5). For five coordinate compounds, the two possible geometries are trigonal bipyramidal (tbp) and square pyramidal (sqp). Hence, we can say that in the solution phase at room temperature, 7–12 exist as a mixture of two species with trigonal bipyramidal and square pyramidal geometry. This is evident in solution from the splitting pattern observed for the methylene protons for 7–12. Two sets of peaks are observed for the methylene protons (δ = 4.83–5.38 ppm and δ = 4.63–4.83 ppm) due to the existence of two species in solution. The downfield signal (δ = 4.83–5.38 ppm) is further split into four signals which is attributed to AB q , and the upfield signal appears as a broad singlet (δ = 4.63–4.83 ppm). Among the two possible geometries that these compounds can adopt, the methylene protons will be present in a more dissymmetrical environment in the tbp geometry rather than in sqp geometry. Hence, the methylene protons that give the AB q pattern, arise due to species that adopt tbp geometry and the broad singlet arises due to the species with sqp geometry. The coupling constants and chemical shift values corresponding to the AB q are shown in Table S1 (Supporting Information). The diastereotopic methylene proton signal in the sqp geometry appears broad since they cannot be appropriately distinguished on the NMR time scale at room temperature. The expanded spectra for the methylene protons for each compound (7–12) are shown in Fig. S55 (Supporting Information). The percentage of the two species can be estimated from the intensity of the signals corresponding to methyl protons attached to the Al(III) center (Table S2). The methyl signal is chosen for calculating the intensity, as the signal shows no coupling with any other protons, and thus its intensity will have minimum deviation from the actual value. The 13C NMR characterization of 1–12 was in complete agreement with the conclusions from 1H NMR spectroscopic data. For compounds 7–12 two sets of signals were observed for the imine, aromatic and methylene carbon atoms, and broad singlet was observed for the methyl carbon attached to the Al(III) center. The existence of two species in solution was further corroborated from two-dimensional NMR spectroscopy (COZY and HSQC) of compound 9 (Figs. S57a and 7b). To get a better insight into the solution state structure of 7–12, variable-temperature (V-T) 1H NMR study was performed with 9 (CDCl3) between -40 and 55 °C (Fig. S56a). The changes in the chemical shift of the methyl protons, (directly connected to the Al(III) center) with temperature was observed (Fig. S56b). Since the methyl group is directly connected to the metal center, any change in the chemical shift with temperature will be pronounced for these protons. It was observed that at room temperature and above (upto 55 °C), two distinct signals are present (one with more intensity and the other with less intensity) for the methyl protons indicating the presence of two different species (trigonal bipyramidal and square pyramidal geometry) in solution. Below room temperature, at 0 °C only a single peak exists for the methyl protons indicating that at 0 °C, the signals from two species overlap. Below 0 °C, the less intense peak again reappears in the NMR spectrum due to slow exchange between the plausible geometries (trigonal bipyramidal and square pyramidal) at low temperature [51]. The methylene and imine protons are not directly attached to the Al(III) center. Thus, any change in chemical shift values with temperature cannot be readily detected for these protons. The exact mass of the compounds 1–12 obtained from HRMS data matched with the values obtained from the molecular formula derived, based on single-crystal X-ray diffraction and NMR data. 2.2 Single crystal X-ray diffraction studies The aluminum compounds 1, 6 and 11 were characterized by single crystal X-ray diffraction studies. The crystals were obtained from the dilute solution of compounds in toluene, using the slow evaporation method, over a period of 7–10 days. Compounds 1 and 6 crystallize in the space groups P121/c1 and P21/c with 4 and 4 molecules per unit cell respectively. The molecular plot of 1 and 6 is depicted in Figs. 1 and 2 , respectively. Analysis of the crystal data suggests that the Al(III) centers adopt a distorted tetrahedral geometry. In 1, the distance between Al and N1, O1, C17, and C18 were 1.9587(16), 1.7664(14), 1.955(2), and 1.949(2) Å, respectively. In addition, the N1−Al−O1 and C(17)−Al−C(18) angles were 94.58(6)° and 117.59(11)°. The torsion angle for C6−C7−N1−Al and C6−C1−O1−Al were 2.5(3)° and 5.3(3)°. Next, for 6, the distances between the Al center and N1, O1, C8 and C9 are 1.972(2), 1.787(2), 1.947(4), and 1.948(4) Å respectively with the N1−Al−O1 and C(17)−Al−C(18) angles being 93.98(10)° and 119.04(17)°. The torsion angle for C1−C7−N1−Al and C1−C6−O1−Al were 2.7(4)° and 14.7(4)°. In both 1 and 6, the Al atom is situated at 0.454 Å above the phenyl ring plane. In addition, the O1−Al−C17 bond angle in 1 and the O1−Al−C8 bond angle in 6 were found to be 112.85(9)° and 106.72(14)° implying that the furan sidearm in 6 is in close proximity to the Al(III) center as compared to the thiophene side arm in 1. Compound 11 crystallizes in the space group Pca21 with 4 molecules in the unit cell. The distances between the Al center (Fig. 3 ) and N1, N2, O2, O5 and C27 were 2.089(2), 2.083(2), 1.7820(17), 1.7819(18) and 1.965(3) Å respectively. The bond angles of O5−Al−N2, O2−Al−N1, O5−Al−C27, O2−Al−C27, O5−Al−O2 were found to be 88.47(9)°, 84.52(9)°, 116.75(11)°, 120.61(11)°, 122.58 (9)° respectively. Analysis of the bond lengths and angles reveal that 11 adopts a distorted trigonal-bipyramidal geometry (tbp), considering the O2, O5 and C27 atoms forming the equatorial plane containing the Al(III) center with N1 and N2 in the axial position. The Al(III) center is not present in the center of the peritoneal plane. Alternatively, from the same analysis we can conclude a square-pyramidal (sp) geometry with N1, N2, O2 and O5 atoms forming the base and C27 atom as the apex. Such phenomena are well known [53]. The value of geometry index, τ = 0.72 (close to 1) indicated that compound 11, has distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry [52]. 2.3 Lewis acidity of aluminum compounds To get a qualitative idea about the Lewis acidity of aluminum compounds, monoligated compound 1 and bisligated compound 7 was reacted with DMF [54]. It was observed that DMF easily coordinated with bisligated aluminum compound 7, as evident from the downfield shift of ẟ values of DMF due to coordination to the aluminum center. For the monoligated aluminum compound 1, the change in ẟ values compared to free DMF was marginal (Fig. S78). It indicated that although the four coordinated aluminum center in monoligated compound 1 had two potential coordination sites and was expected to be more Lewis acidic, actually, the bisligated compound 7 showed higher Lewis acidity. The bisligated compound 7 coordinated to two nitrogen atoms and two oxygen atoms from the ligand and one carbon from the methyl group have higher Lewis acidity as compared to compound 1 where aluminum center is coordinated to one nitrogen atom, one oxygen atom from ligand and two carbon atoms from two methyl group. Thus, for the monoligated and bisligated aluminum compounds the electronic environment around the aluminum center dictates the Lewis acidity rather than vacant coordination site. 2.4 Ring-opening copolymerization (ROCOP) of CO2 with epoxides Compounds 1–12 were tested as catalysts towards the ROCOP of epoxide (CHO and PO) with CO2. The polymerization conditions were optimized after performing various trial experiments for the ROCOP with 5 at different temperature and pressure. From the analysis of data obtained from the trial experiments, the optimum conditions for the ROCOP of CHO and CO2 were found to be 80 °C, 40 bar CO2 pressure and, for the ROCOP of PO and CO2 the corresponding parameters were found to be 40 °C, 60 bar CO2 pressure respectively. Further, it was observed that when the ROCOP studies for CHO and CO2 were done with (CHO: Catalyst = 1000:1) at 80 °C and 40 bar CO2 pressure for 24 h, only 42% conversion of CHO was achieved with 40% uptake of CO2 in the form of poly(cyclohexene carbonate) (PCHC) and cyclohexene carbonate (CHC) with a turnover number (TON) of 419 and turnover frequency (TOF) of 17 h − 1. The yield of the PCHC was found to be very low (0.31 g), starting from 4 g CHO (Fig. S58). The M n and dispersity (Ð) of the PCHC obtained from this trial were found to be 11.63 and 1.12, respectively. This reveals that cyclic carbonate was formed as the major product with a minor fraction of PCHC under these conditions in the presence of 5 alone. Next, we decided to perform the copolymerization studies in the presence of a cocatalyst with CHO: Catalyst: Cocatalyst = 1000:1:1. The three ionic cocatalysts namely Tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB), bis(triphenylphosphine)iminium chloride (PPNCl) and Tetraphenylphosphonium chloride (TPPCl) were screened for the ROCOP of CHO with CO2 using 5 as the catalyst (Entries 1–3, Table 1 ). It was observed that with the variation of the cocatalysts, the overall conversion of CHO was almost comparable, but the formation of PCHC differed to a greater extent. It was observed that the selectivity for the formation of the linear chain polycarbonate (PCHC) was least (48%) when TBAB was used as a cocatalyst. This is because Br− being a good leaving group facilitated the formation of the cyclic carbonate product through a reaction pathway shown in Scheme 3 [55]. Between TPPCl and PPNCl as cocatalyst, the conversion to linear chain aliphatic polycarbonate was higher when TPPCl was used as cocatalyst. A plausible reason for this observation is that the release of the Cl− ion is easier from TPPCl compared to PPNCl. In case of TPPCl, when the Cl− ion is released, the positive charge resides on the phosphorus atom and the phenyl rings. This is more favourable than in PPNCl where the positive charge is delocalized over the electronegative nitrogen atom as well. Further studies were done by increasing the amount of cocatalyst (TPPCl) to two equivalents with respect to 5. On increasing the amount of cocatalyst, the percentage of cyclic carbonate increased. A plausible reason for such an observation is that on increasing the amount of cocatalyst, easy dissociation of the growing polymer chain from the metal center may occur, making the backbiting reaction more favourable following the route shown in Scheme 4 [56]. Since increasing the amount of TPPCl was found to be detrimental for ROCOP, the optimum stoichiometric ratio between the epoxide, catalyst and cocatalyst (at temperature and pressure mentioned earlier) was [Epoxide]: [Catalyst]:[Cocatalyst] = 1000:1:1. The outcome of the ROCOP are summarized in Tables 1 and 2 for CHO and PO respectively. The studies showed that for the ROCOP of CHO with CO2, nature of the side arm attached to an imine nitrogen atom (furan-2-ylmethanimine and thiophen-2-ylmethanimine) has no significant effect on polymerization as evidenced by the less variation of TOF values (Entries 4 vs. 7, 5 vs. 2, 6 vs. 8, etc. in Table 1). It was observed that when compounds with the same phenolate core and same side arm attached to the imine nitrogen atom were considered, the monoalkyl aluminum compounds (7–12) showed more conversion of epoxides than the dialkyl aluminum compounds (1–6) (Entries 4 vs. 9, 5 vs. 10, 6 vs. 11 etc. in Table 1). For monoalkyl aluminum compounds, the aluminum atom is coordinated to two nitrogen atoms and two oxygen atoms from the ligand and one carbon atom from the methyl group which leads to increase in Lewis acidity of the five-coordinate aluminum center as compared to the four-coordinate aluminum center (as discussed above). Thus, coordination of the epoxide occurs rapidly for the five-coordinate aluminum (7–12) compounds as compared to four-coordinate aluminum compounds (1–6). In addition, it was observed that the percentage of the linear chain polycarbonate formed was higher for the five-coordinate monoalkyl aluminum compounds than the four coordinate dialkyl aluminum compounds (Entries 1 vs. 7, 4 vs. 10, 6 vs. 12 etc. in Table 1). The observation can be accounted for by considering the insertion of carbon dioxide into the aluminum alkoxide bond that results in the formation of carbonate linkage. Once the ring-opening of epoxide occurs and metal alkoxide species is generated, the carbon dioxide must approach the aluminum center from the side of the aluminum alkoxide linkage. The five-coordinate aluminum compounds (7–12) have no other vacant site from where carbon dioxide can approach the metal center, while for the four-coordinate aluminum compounds (1–6), an additional vacant site is present from where carbon dioxide can come close to the metal center. The approach from the additional vacant site for (1–6) is not favorable for the formation of carbonate linkage in the polymer chain (Fig. 4 ). For both the families of Al(III) compounds, the carbonate percentage in the linear chain polycarbonate increased when the phenolate core was substituted with the electron-donating group since it decreases the Lewis acidity of the aluminum center to some extent so that CO2 approach becomes more favourable (Entries 1 vs. 3, 4 vs. 6, 7 vs. 9 etc. in Table 1). Such observations have been rationalised earlier in the literature [44,45]. The copolymers PCHC obtained were isotactic-enriched, as evident from the 13C NMR of the carbonyl region. From the literature, it is known that for m-centered tetrad (mmm and mmr), the 13C resonance of the carbonyl carbon is at ẟ = 153.7 ppm, and for r-centered tetrad (rrr, rmr, rrm, mrm) the corresponding values lie at ẟ = 152.6–153.4 [58]. The values for the percentage of m-centered tetrad for PCHC obtained using all compounds 1–12 are given in Table 1 and the carbonyl region of the PCHC obtained using 7 is shown in Fig. 5 . From the spectrum it is clear that the peak corresponding to the m-centered tetrad at ẟ = 153.76 ppm is the most intense and the r-centered tetrad peak showed minimal intensity relative to the m-centered peak. The percentage of m-centered tetrad for PCHC obtained employing 1–12 was 77–84% indicating the tacticity in the copolymer chain was independent of the geometry adopted by the catalyst. The thermal properties of the isolated PCHC obtained using 7 as the catalyst gave further evidence for the isotactic nature of the copolymer. The DSC thermogram showed T g and T m values at 122 °C and 221 °C (Fig. S70). The values showed little deviation from the literature-reported values for semi-crystalline isotactic PCHC with more than 80% carbonate linkage. The deviation is attributed to negligible polyether linkage in the polycarbonate chain [59]. A small peak at nearly 65 °C, is attributed to minute fraction of polyether present in the polycarbonate [60]. The observed T g value is less than classical bisphenol-A-derived polycarbonate (150 °C) [61,62]. The TGA trace showed that the onset of weight loss for the copolymer (PCHC) was at 225 °C with upto approximately 90% loss occurring at 390 °C (Fig. S71). The PCHC copolymer chain formation was also validated from the MALDI-TOF analysis of the aliphatic polycarbonate (Fig. 6 ). The two major series of peaks- series A (end-capped with chlorine and C6H10OH) and series B (end-capped with chlorine and H +) were observed in the MALDI-TOF mass spectrum. As shown in the MALDI-TOF spectrum, the consecutive peaks in the two series (series A and series B) showed a mass difference 142.1 which is the combined mass of one molecule of CHO (98.14 u) and one molecule of CO2 (44.01 u) taken together. The presence of a minor series (series C) was also detected in the MALDI-TOF spectrum. The mass difference of 98 u between series A and series C gave evidence that the minor series C arose due to polyether linkage in the polymer chain. The three series are end-capped with chlorine at one end, indicating that chloride originating from TPPCl gets attached to the Al(III) center and the six-coordinate aluminum species generated results in the nucleophilic attack by chloride ion for the epoxide ring-opening of CHO. The possibility of cyclohexene diol acting as the chain-transfer agent (as reported by Darensbourg et al. in 2016) [63] due to the presence of extra CHO unit in the MALDI spectrum is eliminated as the GPC traces obtained for the polymers were unimodal (Supporting Information). Thus, the polymerization is free from concomitant moisture. The above findings indicate that ROCOP occurs by a coordination-insertion mechanism [64]. 2.4.1 Rate law for ROCOP of CHO and CO2 To establish the rate law for the ROCOP, thorough kinetics investigations were carried out at 80 °C, the optimum temperature for all the copolymerization studies. The reaction kinetics was studied with respect to the concentration of catalyst, concentration of CHO and pressure of CO2. The kinetic experiments were conducted such that for a particular set of experiments, related to a parameter {[CHO] or [Catalyst] or [Pressure of CO2]},all other parameters were kept constant, except the parameter ({[CHO] or [Catalyst] or [Pressure of CO2]}) against which the kinetics studies were performed. 2.4.1.1 Reaction order with respect to concentration of the catalyst The reaction kinetics with respect to the catalyst was determined by performing the polymerizations at different catalyst concentration (0.2, 0.3, 0.4 and 0.5 mmol) with 10 mL (0.1 mol) of CHO at 80 °C under 40 bar CO2 pressure in a 100 mL high pressure reactor, fitted with an aluminum block heating control and a mechanical stirrer following the general polymerization procedure. At different time intervals, 0.2 mL of aliquots were taken from the reaction mixture and analyzed through 1H NMR studies. The plot of [copolymer] vs. time gave the initial rate with respect to the concentration of the catalyst. The reaction order for the ROCOP with respect to the catalyst was determined by the plot of initial rate vs. [catalyst]. The linear plot suggested that the copolymerization reaction is first-order with respect to the catalyst concentration (Fig. S74). 2.4.1.2 Reaction order with respect to concentration of the cyclohexene oxide (CHO) To determine the reaction order with respect to [CHO], experiments were carried out with [Monomer]: [Catalyst]: [Cocatalyst] = 1000:1: 1 at 80 °C under 40 bar CO2. The aliquots were taken at different time intervals and analyzed by 1H NMR spectroscopy. A plot of {ln([CHO]0/[CHO]t)} vs. time was linear suggesting the copolymerization reaction was first order with respect to concentration of the CHO (Fig. S75). 2.4.1.3 Reaction order in CO2 For investigating the reaction order with respect to pressure of CO2, the ROCOP was carried out by varying the initial pressure of CO2 and keeping the [Catalyst] and [CHO] constant. The pressure range investigated is 5–80 bar. The plot of initial rate vs. CO2 pressure showed that below the pressure of 10 bar, the reaction rate decreases since enough CO2 is not present in the medium to carry out the ROCOP. It is also observed that above 60 bar pressure the initial rate also decreases as due to high pressure of CO2, the system becomes diluted with respect to CHO due to increased amount of CO2 in the reaction medium (Fig. S76). The initial rate was independent of CO2 pressure in the range 10–40 bar suggesting that insertion of CO2 into the metal alkoxide chain generated from the ring-opening of CHO is not the rate-limiting step for the ROCOP. 2.4.2 Mechanistic studies The reaction pathway for the ROCOP of CO2 with CHO is proposed and shown in Scheme 5 . The initiation starts with the coordination of the chloride ion from the phosphonium salt to the Al(III) center, whereby the coordination number of aluminum changes from five to six. The formation of six-coordinate Al(III) species was confirmed from HRMS, whereby a peak corresponding to 649.20 with the molecular formula C35H43AlClN2O2S2 appeared in the mass spectrum when the reaction was carried with an equimolar mixture of 7 and TPPCl at 80 °C in absence of CHO (Fig. S77). The same six coordinate Al(III) species was detected when an aliquot from the polymerization mixture was taken after 2 min from the start of the polymerization and subjected to ESI-MS analysis. The inital propagating species is generated when the epoxide approaches the Al(III) center. The coordination of epoxide to Al(III) center, takes place with the concurrent cleavage of the AlCl bond and the nucleophilic attack by the released chloride to epoxide results in ring-opening. The aluminum alkoxide species generated is the initial active propagating species with the chloride ion at one end. The formation of both initiating and propagating species in the reaction medium was well established when aliquots were taken at different time intervals (10 mins., 20 mins., 30 mins. and 40 mins.) and analyzed by ESI-MS. It was observed that after ten minutes, the only species detected was the H + adduct of the six-coordinate aluminum intermediate that act as the initiating species for the ROCOP (Scheme 5 and Fig. 7 b). As the time elapsed, the peak corresponding to the H + adduct of the aluminum alkoxide (initial propagating species with molecular formula C41H55AlClN2S2O3 and molecular mass 749.3158) appeared in the mass spectrum and at the end of 40 min, the intensity of the peak corresponding to the initiating species in the mass spectrum decreased. The insertion of CO2 into the metal-alkoxide bond generates the aliphatic polycarbonate. The carbonate intermediate generated then attacks another epoxide molecule to give a new metal alkoxide species, and the chain propagation continues with repeating cycles between metal alkoxide and metal carbonate species. The increase in the carbonate content in the polymer chain was detected from the increase in the intensity of carbonyl stretching frequency in the IR spectrum of the polymer sample quenched at a different time intervals (4 h, 8 h, 12 h and 16 h), since in-situ monitoring was not possible due to instrumental limitations (Fig. 7a). The cyclic product was generated by the back-biting reaction occurring in the growing polymer chain [18]. The polyether content in the polymer chain arises when the carbonate intermediate attacks more than one molecule of the epoxide [18]. Finally, the polymer chain is terminated by the hydrolysis of aluminum-oxygen bond with the addition of acidified methanol. The unimodal mass distribution in the GPC trace and presence of chloride (Cl ) as the end group as observed in MALDI-TOF mass spectrum indicated that only one type of polymer chain grows from the Al(III) center since the growth of any other type of polymer chain would have resulted in alkyl or phenoxide as end groups. Next, all the aluminum compounds (1–12) were employed for the ROCOP studies using propylene oxide (PO) as the monomer. The polymerization conditions were optimised after performing trial experiments using compound 5. The polymerization with 5 in the presence of cocatalyst with [Monomer]/[Cat]/[Cocat] = 1000:1:1 and at 40 °C and 60 bar CO2 pressure gave satisfactory yield (0.91 g) starting from 3 g of PO. The M n and dispersity (Ð) of the PPC obtained from this trial were found to be 18.60 and 1.10 respectively with TOF value of 56 h − 1. On increasing the temperature to 80 °C and 120 °C (Entries 1 and 2, Table 2) resulted in formation of propylene carbonate (cyclic product) as the exclusive product. Thus, for all the aluminum compounds the polymerization was performed at 40 °C and 60 bar CO2 pressure with [Monomer]/[Cat]/[Cocat] = 1000:1:1 (Entry 3–13, Table 2). Our catalyst library showed similar activity towards the ROCOP of PO and CO2 to produce PPC as found in the case of PCHC. The time for the polymerization with PO was shorter compared to CHO, as small monomer PO can approach to the aluminum center easily. The attached thiophene and furan portion in the ligand system did not give a significant difference in the polymerization process (except when phenolate core is substituted with methoxy group at the ortho position) as evident from less variation of TOF values (Entries 3 vs. 6, 5 vs. 7, 10 vs. 13 etc. in Table 2). From Table 2, it is evident that the overall conversion of epoxide and formation of linear chain polycarbonates is slightly higher for the five coordinate monoalkyl compounds (7–12) than the four coordinate dialkyl aluminum compounds (1–6). The same reason is applicable for such a phenomenon as described above for ROCOP of CHO and CO2. Nevertheless, within the same family of aluminum compounds (1–6) or (7–12), the attached electron donating and electron withdrawing group in the phenyl part plays a crucial role in the formation of PPC (Table 2 entries 3, 5, 6 and 7). Lowering the Lewis acidity of the Al(III) center through the introduction of electron donating substituents in the phenolate ring of the ligand increases the propensity of CO2 coordination to the polymerization site, leading to greater selectivity towards polycarbonate formation (Table 2 entries 6 and 7). Similar observations were noticed using 7–12 as ROCOP catalysts (Table 2 entries 8–13). The copolymers obtained from ROCOP of PO/CO2 were isotactic with HT content achieved upto 95% as evident from the 13C NMR of the carbonyl region. The carbonyl resonance showed intense peak corresponding to mm triad and absence of mr, rm and rr triad [65]. The percentage of head-to-tail-linkage was independent of the geometry adopted by the Al(III) center. The ring-opening of epoxide takes place by attack on the methine carbon atom. This is evident from the 1H NMR signal of the methine hydrogen which appears at ẟ = 4.9 ppm. If the ring opening of epoxide was from less hindered carbon atom the methine hydrogen signal would appear at ẟ = 3.8 ppm [49]. Moreover, the ROCOP of PO with CO2 is mostly governed by the electronic environment of the phenolate core of the unsymmetrical phenoxy-imine ligand backbone. This is understood from the TOF values. The DSC trace demonstrated that the PPC exhibited a glass transition temperature of 45 °C, (Fig. S72) in agreement with the value reported in the literature [66]. The TGA curve for PPC showed that the onset of decomposition at 190 °C, and about 50% decomposition was complete at approximately 235 °C (Fig. S73). 3 Conclusion In summary, we synthesized two families of mononuclear Al(III) alkyl compounds supported by bidentate N, O phenoxy-imine ligand with thiophen-2-ylmethanimine and furan-2-ylmethanimine side arms. The catalytic behavior of the monoalkyl and dialkyl Al(III) compounds was explored for the ROCOP of CO2 and epoxides (CHO and PO). For the ROCOP of CO2 with epoxides, it was observed that the catalytic activity of the aluminum compounds relied mostly on the geometry adopted by the Al(III) center and the nature of the substituents present in the phenolate core of the phenoxy-imine ligand. It was observed that compounds 7–12 showed superior catalytic properties as compared to compounds 1–6. The higher Lewis acidity of aluminum compounds 7–12 allows easy coordination of epoxides to the aluminum center as compared to compounds 1–6. Also, the geometry adopted by Al (III) compounds (7–12) offers no vacant site for carbon dioxide approach except from the end of the growing aluminum alkoxide chain that led to a more favorable insertion of carbon dioxide into metal alkoxide bond. The formation of aliphatic polycarbonate with minimal polyether linkage was observed when phenolate core was substituted with an electron-donating group as it reduced the Lewis acidity of Al center to some extent such that successive ring-opening of epoxide is prevented. The catalyst library gave isotactic PCHC and PPC. The kinetics studies for ROCOP of CHO and CO2 showed that the reaction has first-order dependence on [catalyst] and [CHO] and zero order with respect to CO2 pressure. The ROCOP of CO2 with CHO and PO, with less explored aluminum complexes supported by bidentate monoanionic imino-phenoxy ligand backbone showed good catalytic activity and excellent isotacticity (as shown by higher percentage of m-centered tetrads and triads in the 13C NMR spectrum for PCHC and PPC respectively). Future studies are underway to investigate the catalytic activity of half-salen based gallium and indium compounds for the ROCOP of epoxide and carbon dioxide. 4 Experimental 4.1 Materials and general details All reactions involving air or moisture-sensitive species were carried out using a glovebox or standard Schlenk line techniques. Toluene was dried over sodium and benzophenone and distilled fresh before use. The reagents 2‑tert‑butyl‑4-methylphenol, 4-chlorophenol, 2-methoxyphenol, hexamethylenetetramine, magnesium chloride, triethyl amine, paraformaldehyde, trimethyl aluminum (2 M in hexane), tetraphenylphosphonium chloride (TPPCl) and bis(triphenylphosphine)iminium chloride (PPNCl) were purchased from Sigma-Aldrich. Cyclohexene oxide (CHO) and propylene oxide (PO) was also purchased from Sigma-Aldrich and dried over CaH2 and distilled fresh before use. Tetraphenylphosphonium chloride (TPPCl), bis(triphenylphosphine)iminium chloride (PPNCl) were purified by crystallization from chloroform and hexane and dried in vacuum before use. Tetrabutylammonium bromide (TBAB) was crystallized from toluene and dried in vacuum. CDCl3 used for NMR spectral measurements was dried over calcium hydride and stored in a glove box after distillation. NMR spectra were recorded on Bruker Avance-400 and Bruker Avance-500 instruments. All spectra were processed using Topspin software. ESI-MS spectra were recorded using a Waters Q-Tof micromass spectrometer. MALDI-TOF measurements were done on a Bruker Daltonics or Bruker Ultraflextreme instrument in dihydroxybenzoic acid (DHBA) matrix. Research grade CO2 gas for the ROCOP studies was purchased from Indogas, Bangalore, India. GPC analysis was carried out on a WATERS LC-20AD instrument equipped with a refractive index (RI) detector. HPLC-grade THF was used as the eluent, at 0.8 mL/min, at 40 °C. Before analysis samples were filtered through 0.2 μm PTFE filters. To calibrate the instrument, narrow-Mn polystyrene standards were used. The preparation of ligands along with characterization data is discussed in Supplementary Information. 4.2 Synthesis of compounds 1–12 A general procedure for the synthesis of 1–6 is outlined below: In an argon filled glove box, AlMe3 (2 M in hexane, 0.34 mmol) was added to a solution L1, L2, L3, L4, L5 and L6 (0.34 mmol) in 5 mL of dry toluene at –24 °C. The reaction mixture was allowed to attain room temperature and stirred for additional 8 h. The solvent was removed under vacuum and the yellow residue obtained was crystallized from concentrated toluene solution at –24 °C. A general procedure for the synthesis of 7–12 is outlined below: In an argon filled glove box, AlMe3 (2 M in hexane, 0.34 mmol) was added to a solution L1, L2, L3, L4, L5 and L6 (0.68 mmol) in 5 mL of dry toluene at –24 °C. The reaction mixture was allowed to attain room temperature and stirred for additional 8 h. Mp: 220 °C. 1H NMR (400 MHz, CDCl3, 300 K): δ (ppm) = – 0.96 (s, 1H), – 0.88 (s, 2H), 4.69 (s, 2H), 4.89–5.01 (dd, J = 16 Hz, 2H), 6.40 (s, 3H), 6.73–6.81 (m, 3H), 7.10–7.47 (m, 6H), 7.88 (s, 1H), 8.06 (s, 1H). 13C NMR (100 MHz, CDCl3, 300 K): δ (ppm) = – 10.79, 51.47, 52.68, 110.70, 110.86, 110.94, 111.31, 119.34, 120.42, 121.31, 121.74, 122.78, 123.38, 132.09, 133.08, 134.39, 136.86, 143.31, 143.96, 146.98, 149.61, 162.15, 162.81, 165.82, 169.85. ESI m/z calculated for [M]+.C25H21AlCl2N2O4: 510.0694, found 510.0691. Anal. Calc. for 12, C25H21AlCl2N2O4: C, 58.72; H, 4.14; N, 5.48. Found: C, 58.74; H, 4.13; N, 5.46. 4.3 X-ray structure determination of complex 1, 6 and 11 Suitable single crystals for X-ray diffraction studies were obtained for complex 1, 6 and 11. Single crystals were grown in a glove box by concentrated toluene solutions of the respective compounds over a period of 7–10 days. X-ray data was collected with a Bruker AXS (Kappa Apex 2) CCD diffractometer equipped with graphite monochromatic Mo (Kα) (wavelength 0.7107 Å) radiation source. The data was collected with 100% completeness for theta up to 25° The frames were then subjected for integration and data were reduced for Lorentz and polarization corrections using SAINT-NT. The multi-scan absorption correction was then applied to the data set. All structures were solved using SIR-92 and refinement was done using SHELXL-97. These data were deposited with CCDC with the following numbers: CCDC 2,106,313 for 1, CCDC 2,106,315 for 6 and CCDC 2,106,314 for 11. coredata.dc:description: The synthesis and characterization of two different categories of Al(III) compounds supported by unsymmetrical phenoxy-imine ligands with furan-2-ylmethanimine and thiophen-2-ylmethanimine side arms is described. Reactions of the ligands with Al(CH3)3 in a 1:1 and 2:1 stoichiometric ratio resulted in the formation of the corresponding monosubstituted and disubstituted Al(III) compounds in quantitative yields. These compounds were fully characterized using various spectroscopic techniques and elemental analysis. Single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies revealed that the Al(III) center in the monosubstituted compounds adopt a distorted tetrahedral geometry while those in the disubstituted compounds adopt a distorted trigonal bipyramidal geometry with a geometric index τ = 0.72. These compounds along with tetraphenylphosphonium chloride (TPPCl) form a binary catalyst system for the ring-opening copolymerization (ROCOP) of CO2 with cyclohexene oxide (CHO) and propylene oxide (PO). They show notable activity producing alternating polycarbonate with TOF up to 107 h−1 and high selectivity (carbonate linkages > 80%). The catalytic activities of the compounds have been investigated by varying the substituent in the phenolate core and in the imine backbone.
coredata.dc:title: Ring-opening copolymerization of CO2 with epoxides catalyzed by binary catalysts containing half salen aluminum compounds and quaternary phosphonium salt
